citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
On March 27th, 2025, 12 cats arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport (Queens, New York) from Tashkent
International Airport (Tashkent, Uzbekistan) on Uzbekistan Airways (flight # HY101).
Three transport enclosures did not have the words “Live Animals,” the enclosures also did not display any markings
indicating the correct upright position. To ensure proper handling and safety of the animals, clear markings indicating the
presence of live animals and the correct orientation of transport containers must be present. Unless the enclosure is
permanently affixed to the conveyance, each enclosure must be clearly marked on top and on one or more sides the
words “Live Animals” in letters at least 1 inch high, and with arrows or other markings to indicate the correct upright
position of the primary enclosure .

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
On March 27th, 2025, 12 cats arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport (Queens, New York) from Tashkent
International Airport (Tashkent, Uzbekistan) on Uzbekistan Airways (flight # HY101).
Multiple primary enclosures within this shipment surpassed the maximum number of animals allowed by air carriers.
Three kittens were present in each of three separate primary enclosures. Multiple animals within one carrier can lead to
combability issues, excessive stress, and physical hazards. Air travel can pose increased risk, especially animals within
cargo, due to the inability to remedy any of the risk listed above. No more than two live kittens, 8 weeks to 6 months of
age, that are of comparable size can be transported in the same primary enclosure when shipped via air carrier.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with handler and airline representatives.
n

narrative:
3.15(a)(6) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats. 
On March 27th, 2025, 12 cats arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport (Queens, New York) from Tashkent 
International Airport (Tashkent, Uzbekistan) on Uzbekistan Airways (flight # HY101). 
 
Three transport enclosures did not have the words “Live Animals,” the enclosures also did not display any markings 
indicating the correct upright position. To ensure proper handling and safety of the animals, clear markings indicating the 
presence of live animals and the correct orientation of transport containers must be present. Unless the enclosure is 
permanently affixed to the conveyance, each enclosure must be clearly marked on top and on one or more sides the 
words “Live Animals” in letters at least 1 inch high, and with arrows or other markings to indicate the correct upright 
position of the primary enclosure . 
3.15(f)(3) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats. 
On March 27th, 2025, 12 cats arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport (Queens, New York) from Tashkent 
International Airport (Tashkent, Uzbekistan) on Uzbekistan Airways (flight # HY101). 
 
Multiple primary enclosures within this shipment surpassed the maximum number of animals allowed by air carriers. 
Three kittens were present in each of three separate primary enclosures. Multiple animals within one carrier can lead to 
combability issues, excessive stress, and physical hazards. Air travel can pose increased risk, especially animals within 
cargo, due to the inability to remedy any of the risk listed above. No more than two live kittens, 8 weeks to 6 months of 
age, that are of comparable size can be transported in the same primary enclosure when shipped via air carrier. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with handler and airline representatives.
